required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Effect of Weight Loss on Urinary Oxalate Excretion in Obese Calcium Oxalate Kidney Stone Formers
clinical_study.official_title: Effect of Weight Loss on Urinary Oxalate Excretion in Obese Calcium Oxalate Kidney Stone

collaborator.agency: University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center

brief_summary.textblock: This protocol seeks to determine if weight reduction with the Optifast VLCD program leads to reduced contribution of endogenous oxalate synthesis to the urinary oxalate pool in obese calcium oxalate stone formers.

primary_outcome.measure: Measurement of 24 hour urinary oxalate excretion
primary_outcome.description: Subjects will ingest a controlled diet low in oxalate and collect 2 x 24-hour urines before and after the Optifast VLCD Program. The utilization of a low oxalate diet allows assessment of the change in contribution of endogenous oxalate synthesis to the urinary oxalate pool.

arm_group.arm_group_label: Controlled Diet and Weight Loss Program
arm_group.description: Subjects will consume a low oxalate diet with blood and urine collections to establish baseline levels before undergoing a weight loss program with Optifast VLCD products. After completing the weight loss program, subjects will once again consume a low oxalate diet with blood and urine collections to observe any changes that may have occurred due to the weight loss.

intervention.description: Subjects will be instructed to ingest a controlled diet low in oxalate for a total of 7 days
intervention.arm_group_label: Controlled Diet and Weight Loss Program

intervention.intervention_name: Oral load of oxalate and sucralose
intervention.description: Subjects will ingest 4 mmoles of sodium oxalate, which includes 50mg carbon-13 oxalate, and 5 grams of sucralose on the last day of the 7-day low oxalate diet phase. Following the oral load, blood and urine will be collected every 30 minutes and hourly, respectively
intervention.arm_group_label: Controlled Diet and Weight Loss Program

intervention.description: Subjects will go on a 12-week Intestive level Optifast VLCD weight loss program
intervention.arm_group_label: Controlled Diet and Weight Loss Program

intervention.description: After completion of the 12-week Optifast VLCD Program, subjects will be weaned off the Optifast products for 2 weeks.
intervention.arm_group_label: Controlled Diet and Weight Loss Program

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Calcium Oxalate Stone Formers (CaOx SF): last stone composition greater than 50% CaOx
- Last stone passage or removal greater than 3 months prior to screening
- Body Mass Index (BMI) between 30 and 45 kg/m2
- Able to provide consent
- Normal fasting serum electrolytes on comprehensive metabolic profile
- 24-hour urine collection with creatinine within 20% of gender appropriate (mg creat/kg body weight) and consistent between collections (within 20% of each other)
- Willing to ingest menus prepared at the University of Alabama and University of Texas Southwestern Clinical Research Units
- Willing to consume the Optifast VLCD diet
- No food allergies/intolerance to any of the foods in study menus
- Willing to avoid vigorous exercise during eucaloric, low-oxalate dietary phase
- Willing to stop use of weight-loss medications
- Willing to stop for 14 days before and during study: medications for stone prevention including diuretics, potassium citrate, allopurinol, febuxostat, and calcium, nutritional, or herbal supplements
Exclusion Criteria:
- Renal colic in the past 3 months
- Estimated Glomerular Filtration Rate (eGFR) less than 60 ml/min/1.73m2
- History of type 2 diabetes or screening hgb A1c greater than or equal to 6.5%
- Alcohol or drug abuse
- Mental/medical condition likely to impede study completion
- Fertility issues, current/planned pregnancy or breastfeeding in coming 6 months
- Febrile illness including flu/common cold/COVID-19 within 21 days of study start
- Primary or enteric hyperoxaluria
- Gastrointestinal disorder or surgery that impacts oxalate transport
- Cirrhosis, pancreatic or biliary disorder, porphyria, gout
- Malignancy treated within the past 12 months
- Nephrotic syndrome, neurogenic bladder, urinary diversion
- History of primary hyperparathyroidism, cystinuria, renal tubular acidosis, sarcoidosis, cystic fibrosis
- Uncontrolled hypertension, myocardial infarction in past 6 months, unstable angina, congestive heart failure
- Antibiotic use in last 6 months
- Medications: Topiramate, acetazolamide, zonisamide, diuretics, SGLT2-inhibitors, immunosuppressants
